articles.headline: Stranded in North Carolina’s Mountains, ‘You Can’t Tell That the World’s Going On’
articles.snippet: With no way for cars to get into Bat Cave, N.C., food and water have been dropped off by helicopters or carried over the river on foot or by a raft.
articles.abstract: With no way for cars to get into Bat Cave, N.C., food and water have been dropped off by helicopters or carried over the river on foot or by a raft.
articles.lead_paragraph: Morgan Ladlee and her fiancé loaded their backpacks with supplies and began a journey up the mountain that, a week ago, would have taken about five minutes by car.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Christian Monterrosa

articles.headline: Judge Unseals New Evidence in Federal Election Case Against Trump
articles.snippet: Judge Tanya Chutkan made public portions of a filing by prosecutors setting out their argument for why the case should go forward despite the Supreme Court’s ruling on presidential immunity.
articles.abstract: Judge Tanya Chutkan made public portions of a filing by prosecutors setting out their argument for why the case should go forward despite the Supreme Court’s ruling on presidential immunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: When told by an aide that Vice President Mike Pence was in peril as the rioting on Capitol Hill escalated on Jan. 6, 2021, President Donald J. Trump replied, “So what?”
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Israel Says at Least 8 Soldiers Are Killed in Clashes With Hezbollah
articles.snippet: The cross-border fighting appeared to be the first direct ground confrontation between the two sides since Israel invaded Lebanon this week.
articles.abstract: The cross-border fighting appeared to be the first direct ground confrontation between the two sides since Israel invaded Lebanon this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli troops and Hezbollah militants said on Wednesday that they were fighting at close range in southern Lebanon, in what appeared to be the first direct ground confrontation between the two sides since the Israeli invasion began.
articles.byline: By Euan Ward, Liam Stack, Farnaz Fassihi, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: In Japan’s Countryside, Century-Old Firms Learn to Embrace Foreign Workers
articles.snippet: Japan’s regional economies are facing severe labor shortages. Their survival depends on their ability to persuade foreign workers to stay.
articles.abstract: Japan’s regional economies are facing severe labor shortages. Their survival depends on their ability to persuade foreign workers to stay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Hizatsuki Confectionery hired its first foreign workers.
articles.byline: By River Akira Davis and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: The Private Life of Telegram’s Founder Adds to His Troubles
articles.snippet: The mother of three children with Pavel Durov has poked holes in the Russian tech titan’s carefully managed image through a criminal complaint and her account of their opulent lifestyle.
articles.abstract: The mother of three children with Pavel Durov has poked holes in the Russian tech titan’s carefully managed image through a criminal complaint and her account of their opulent lifestyle.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many of their nearly 10 years as romantic partners, Irina Bolgar said, she and Pavel Durov enjoyed a luxurious lifestyle. The extravagance grew as Telegram, the messaging app Mr. Durov created, became a worldwide hit and cemented him as a billionaire and one of the world’s most powerful tech executives.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: To Revive Manufacturing, How Much Can a President Do?
articles.snippet: The policy focus on the industry has changed from job quantity to job quality. And while federal incentives matter, local factors are more important.
articles.abstract: The policy focus on the industry has changed from job quantity to job quality. And while federal incentives matter, local factors are more important.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, the presidential candidates have been tussling over a familiar campaign issue in postindustrial America: how to reinvigorate manufacturing.

articles.headline: When the North Carolina Mountains Become Hurricane Alley
articles.snippet: Most of the deaths from Hurricane Helene occurred far from Florida, where the storm first made landfall. Experts say alerts and evacuation orders need to target inland residents too.
articles.abstract: Most of the deaths from Hurricane Helene occurred far from Florida, where the storm first made landfall. Experts say alerts and evacuation orders need to target inland residents too.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the warnings first arrived, days before the remnants of Hurricane Helene, Kimberly Moody took note of what was said — and what wasn’t. The storm was going to be bad, that much was clear. But no one said she needed to start packing.
articles.byline: By Jenna Russell, Emily Cochrane, Edgar Sandoval and Mark Barrett

articles.headline: After Successes, Israel’s Military Is in a ‘Long Game’ With No Clear Outcome
articles.snippet: A year after perhaps the worst military and intelligence debacle in the country’s history, its armed forces have regained the momentum. Some ask: to what end?
articles.abstract: A year after perhaps the worst military and intelligence debacle in the country’s history, its armed forces have regained the momentum. Some ask: to what end?
articles.lead_paragraph: When thousands of Hamas-led gunmen breached the Gaza border last Oct. 7 and overran Israeli communities, army bases and a music festival, victims of the surprise assault sent desperate messages to loved ones from their hiding places and safe rooms.

articles.headline: ‘They Can’t Survive Too Long’: The Union Leader Who Shut Down the Ports Is Playing Hardball
articles.snippet: Harold J. Daggett is seeking big raises for longshoremen on the East and Gulf Coasts who have fallen behind workers on the West Coast.
articles.abstract: Harold J. Daggett is seeking big raises for longshoremen on the East and Gulf Coasts who have fallen behind workers on the West Coast.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly two decades ago, Harold J. Daggett was accused of being part of the mob’s efforts to control a powerful union, the International Longshoremen’s Association.
